text: The Nok culture, thriving in present-day Kaduna and Plateau States, crafted terracotta figures as early as 1000 BC, marking one of Africa's oldest known sculptural traditions!
Igbo-Ukwu bronzes, dating back to the 9th century in Anambra State, are celebrated as some of the earliest and most intricate metalworks in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Benin City’s bronze plaques, produced since the 13th century by the Edo people, are renowned for their detailed depictions of royal life and history.
Yoruba Gele headwraps, a vibrant tradition from Southwestern Nigeria, symbolize elegance, status, and cultural pride among Yoruba women.
Hausa embroidery, originating from Northern Nigeria, showcases intricate patterns and vibrant colors, reflecting the region’s rich textile heritage.
The Owo terracotta heads, discovered in Ondo State and dating to the 12th–15th centuries, highlight the sophisticated artistry of the Yoruba people.
The Kanuri people of Borno State are known for their elaborate calabash carvings, a craft passed down through generations since at least the 16th century.
